# Introduction

This is the beginning of my WDI 2022 analysis report.

## Load the Dataset

```{python}
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset (make sure wdi.csv is in the same repo, e.g. data/wdi.csv)
df = pd.read_csv("wdi.csv")

# Show the shape and first few rows
print("Shape:", df.shape)

## Exploratory Data Analysis

# 1. GDP per Capita – check min and max
print("GDP per Capita (min, max):", df["gdp_per_capita"].min(), df["gdp_per_capita"].max())

# 2. Life Expectancy – check mean and median
print("Life Expectancy (mean, median):", df["life_expectancy"].mean(), df["life_expectancy"].median())

# 3. Inflation Rate – show summary stats
print("Inflation Rate Summary:")
print(df["inflation_rate"].describe())
``` 

## Summary of Findings

* **GDP per Capita**: Countries range from very low income (~250) to very high income (~226,000). This shows large global inequality.
* **Life Expectancy**: Average life expectancy is about 73 years, median slightly higher at 74. This indicates most countries are clustered in the 70s, with a few low outliers.
* **Inflation Rate**: Average inflation is about 12%, but with high variation (std ≈ 19). The maximum is extremely high (171%), showing some countries experience hyperinflation. The distribution is right-skewed.

## Visualizations

### HScatter plot of GDP per Capita and Life Expectancy

```{python}
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy (WDI 2022). Source: World Bank [@wdi2022]."
#| fig-alt: "Scatter plot of GDP per Capita and Life Expectancy."
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(df["gdp_per_capita"], df["life_expectancy"], alpha=0.6)
plt.title("GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy")
plt.xlabel("GDP per Capita")
plt.ylabel("Life Expectancy (years)")
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
``` 

As shown in @tbl-key-stats, GDP per Capita varies widely across countries, 
while Life Expectancy is much more concentrated.



### Bar Chart: Inflation Rate Quartiles

```{python}
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Inflation Rate Quantiles (1%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 99%) from WDI 2022. Source: World Bank [@wdi2022]."
#| fig-alt: "Bar chart of inflation rate quantiles."
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

infl_quartiles = df["inflation_rate"].quantile([0.01, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.99])

plt.figure(figsize=(6,4))
plt.bar(infl_quartiles.index.astype(str), infl_quartiles.values,
        color="skyblue", edgecolor="black")
plt.title("Inflation Rate Quantiles")
plt.xlabel("Quantile")
plt.ylabel("Inflation Rate (%)")
plt.show()
``` 

Global inflation trends have also been highlighted in the IMF’s World Economic Outlook [@imf2022], 
which emphasizes the risks of high price volatility across emerging markets.
